intro: Xylophacos subvillosus, commonly known as the silky wood-rush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, commonly known as the sedge family, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with narrow, linear leaves. The plant produces small, clustered inflorescences that bear tiny, inconspicuous flowers, typical of many sedges. Xylophacos subvillosus thrives in moist, well-drained soils, often found in woodland edges or wetlands. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, supporting various pollinators and soil organisms.
